facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1039 of 1963 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1039 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 24, 1959 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Second Appeal No. 8 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 24, 1959 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Second Appeal No. 8 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1039 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 24, 1959 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Civil Second Appeal No. 8 of 1957.

facts.text: Respondents filed suit against appellant for recovery of possession of plaint-schedule land of 57.07 acres in Mauza Bhanpur, Tahsil Huzur, Western District Bhopal claiming to be khatedars.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, claiming to be the khatedars of an extent of 57.07 acres of land in Mauza Bhanpur, Tahsil Huzur, Western District Bhopal, filed a suit against the appellant on the ground that the latter was in illegal possession thereof.

facts.text: Appellant contested suit claiming to be khatedar of the land and in possession in that capacity.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit mainly on the ground that he was the khatedar of the said land and that he was in possession thereof in that capacity.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded title declared by Tahsildar in ejectment application under Bhopal State Land Revenue Act, 1932 barring civil court suit.

anchor.surface_text: He also pleaded that his title to the property was declared by the Tahsildar in an application for ejectment filed by him against the respondents under the Bhopal State Land Revenue Act, 1932  Act No. IV of 1932 , hereinafter called the Act, and that the said decision would be a bar to the maintainability of the suit in a civil companyrt.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Bhopal held respondents were khatedars and in possession, suit maintainable in civil court.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge, Bhopal, held that the res- pondents were the khatedars of the suit land and that they had been in possession thereof in that capacity. He held that the suit was maintainable in a civil companyrt.

facts.text: Additional District Judge agreed with trial court findings on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the Additional District Judge agreed with the findings arrived at by the trial companyrt.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Shiv Dayal J., admitted affidavits as evidence, held same conclusion on title and jurisdiction, dismissed second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On second appeal to the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Shiv Dayal, J., of that Court, after admitting certain numberifications as evidence, came to the same companyclusion both on the question of title and on the question of jurisdiction. In the result he dismissed the second appeal.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit under s.71 of the Act in Tahsildar court, Tahsil Huzur, Bhopal for ejectment of respondents as shikmi tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant as khatedar of the land in dispute had filed a suit under s. 71 of the Act in the companyrt of the Tahsildar, Tahsil Huzur, Bhopal for the ejectment of the respondents on the ground that they were his shikmi tenants.

facts.text: Tahsildar held appellant was khatedar and respondents were shikmi tenants.

anchor.surface_text: The said companyrt held that the appellant was the khatedar of the land in dispute and the respon- dents were his shikmi tenants.

facts.text: Patta granted in favour of ancestors of respondents in 1929.

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellant then companytended that though the patta was granted in favour of the ancestors of the respondents in the year 1929 it was revoked later on,

facts.text: Under new settlement of 1935, appellant's name recorded in register of rights.

anchor.surface_text: that under the new settlement of 1935 the appellants name was recorded in the register of rights,

facts.text: Appellant's name continued in khasras up to 1953 as owner.

anchor.surface_text: that in subsequent khasras up to 1953 his name companytinued to be shown as the owner of the suit land

facts.text: Respondents dispossessed of land on March 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: but as they were dispossessed of the land on March 5, 1953, subsequent to the filing of the suit,

facts.text: Suit originally filed for declaration of title, amended on July 24, 1954 for possession.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was originally filed by the respondents for a declaration of their title to the suit property, but as they were dispossessed of the land on March 5, 1953, subsequent to the filing of the suit, the plaint was amended on july 24, 1954, praying for delivery of possession.

facts.text: Lower courts found respondents established title after considering oral and documentary evidence.

anchor.surface_text: But a perusal of the judgments of the companyrts below shows that all the companyrts, after taking into companysideration the entire oral and documentary evidence, came to the companyclusion that the respondents had established their title.

facts.text: High Court admitted notifications re settlement as fresh evidence, held they did not show patta cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: It also admitted the numberifications in respect of the settlement as fresh evidence and, after companysidering them, held that they did number disclose that the patta issued in favour of the respondents ancestors was cancelled.

facts.text: Title to land disputed between parties.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, claiming to be the khatedars of an extent of 57.07 acres of land in Mauza Bhanpur, Tahsil Huzur, Western District Bhopal, filed a suit against the appellant on the ground that the latter was in illegal possession thereof. The appellant companytested the suit mainly on the ground that he was the khatedar of the said land and that he was in possession thereof in that capacity.

facts.text: Suit not barred by limitation under Art. 142 of Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: To such a suit Art. 142 of the Limitation Act applies. The suit is, therefore, clearly number barred by limitation.

facts.text: Civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suit based on title for possession.

concepts.unlisted_description: Jurisdiction to try all civil suits unless barred

anchor.surface_text: Section 200 ( i ) Except as otherwise provided in this Act, or in any other enactment for the time being in force no civil court shall entertain any suit instituted or application made to obtain a decision or order on any matter which the Government or any revenue officer is, by this Act, empowered to determine, decide or dispose of,

concepts.interpretation: Bars civil court only on matters revenue officer empowered to decide; does not bar title suits as no such empowerment for title.

anchor.surface_text: Section 93. ( 1 ) If any dispute arises about any entry to be made in any document of the record of rights, the Tahsildar or other officer preparing the record shall inquire into it summarily and shall pass such order as he thinks fit. Such order, if passed with reference to any entry in the register of rights, shall not be subject to appeal, but no such order shall debar any person from establishing any right to land in a civil court,

concepts.interpretation: Tahsildar decides disputes summarily; order on register not appealable but does not bar civil suit on title; civil court can alter entry.

arguments.claim: Civil court has jurisdiction as suit based on title unless expressly or impliedly barred; party ousting jurisdiction must prove; ouster strictly construed

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 9 of the Code of Civil Procedure, a civil court can entertain a suit of a civil nature except a suit of which its cognizance is either expressly or impliedly barred. It is settled principle that it is for the party who seeks to oust the jurisdiction of a civil court to establish his contention. It is also equally well settled that a statute ousting the jurisdiction of a civil court must be strictly construed.

arguments.claim: s.71 does not empower decision on title, only ejectment of shikmi on specified grounds assuming landlord-tenant relation

anchor.surface_text: The first section relied upon in that context is s. 71, which reads A shikmi may be ejected by order of the Tahsildar if he fails to vacate land on the termination of his lawful possession or does anything in contravention of his agree- ment, if any, provided that no ejectment shall take effect before the commencement of the next agricultural year. Shikmi is defined under the Act to mean a person who holds land from an occupant... Section 71, therefore, presupposes the existence of a legal relationship of landlord and tenant... it does not comprehend a decision on a question of title.

arguments.claim: Provisions on Record of Rights (ss.89,92,93,95) do not bar civil suit on title; s.93 expressly states order does not debar establishing right in civil court; s.95 creates only rebuttable presumption

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions are as follows Section 89. The Record of rights... Section 92. No entry... Section 93. (1) If any dispute... shall not debar any person from establishing any right to land in a civil court... Section 95. Any entry... presumed to be correct until the contrary is proved... The effect of such an entry, therefore, is only to make it a presumptive piece of evidence in a collateral proceeding... Not only s. 95 does not by necessary implication bar a suit but also assumes that in such a suit the correctness of such an entry could be questioned subject to the said presumption.

arguments.claim: Precedents cited by appellant (Gokhul Sahu v. Jodu Nundun Roy and Jatindra Nath Chowdhury v. Azizur Rahaman) not applicable as provisions not in pari materia

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant, in support of his contention, relied upon Gokhul Sahu v. Jodu Nundun Roy, and Jatindra Nath Chowdhury v. Azizur Rahaman Shanao. Those decisions turned upon provisions which are not in pari materia with those with which we are not concerned. They do not, therefore, throw any light on the construction of the relevant provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict construction of ouster clauses under s.9 CPC; s.200 bars only matters expressly empowered to revenue officers; s.71 limited to ejectment assuming tenancy; Record of Rights provisions (ss.89-95) create rebuttable presumption and expressly preserve civil jurisdiction under s.93.

holdings.text: Section 71 presupposes the existence of a legal relationship of landlord and tenant and enables the occupant to evict his shikmi... it does not comprehend a decision on a question of title.

anchor.surface_text: The first section relied upon in that companytext is s. 71, which reads A shikmi may be ejected by order of the Tahsildar if he fails to vacate land on the termination of his lawful possession or does anything in companytravention of his agree- ment, if any,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation of s.71: empowers ejectment on specific grounds post-assuming tenancy relation; title extraneous to scope.

holdings.text: The effect of such an entry [in register of rights] is only to make it a presumptive piece of evidence in a collateral proceeding... Not only s. 95 does not by necessary implication bar a suit but also assumes that in such a suit the correctness of such an entry could be questioned subject to the said presumption.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.89,92,93,95 analyzed: s.93 expressly non-debarring of civil suits; s.95 rebuttable presumption only, harmonious reading preserves title jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: We are number, therefore, justified in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution to permit the appellant to canvass the correctness of the said concurrent findings of fact. The last argument raises a question of limitation. If, as we have held, the suit is outside the scope of the Act, the question of limitation turns upon the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act. The suit was originally filed by the respondents for a declaration of their title to the suit property, but as they were dispossessed of the land on March 5, 1953, subsequent to the filing of the suit, the plaint was amended on july 24, 1954, praying for delivery of possession. To such a suit Art. 142 of the Limitation Act applies. The suit is, therefore, clearly number barred by limitation.

outcome.relief_summary: Civil court jurisdiction upheld; concurrent findings on title upheld; suit not barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: We are number, therefore, justified in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution to permit the appellant to canvass the correctness of the said concurrent findings of fact. The last argument raises a question of limitation. If, as we have held, the suit is outside the scope of the Act, the question of limitation turns upon the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act. The suit was originally filed by the respondents for a declaration of their title to the suit property, but as they were dispossessed of the land on March 5, 1953, subsequent to the filing of the suit, the plaint was amended on july 24, 1954, praying for delivery of possession. To such a suit Art. 142 of the Limitation Act applies. The suit is, therefore, clearly number barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We are number, therefore, justified in an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution to permit the appellant to canvass the correctness of the said concurrent findings of fact. The last argument raises a question of limitation. If, as we have held, the suit is outside the scope of the Act, the question of limitation turns upon the provisions of the Indian Limitation Act. The suit was originally filed by the respondents for a declaration of their title to the suit property, but as they were dispossessed of the land on March 5, 1953, subsequent to the filing of the suit, the plaint was amended on july 24, 1954, praying for delivery of possession. To such a suit Art. 142 of the Limitation Act applies. The suit is, therefore, clearly number barred by limitation.

Issue on vitiation of concurrent finding is addressed by holding refusing interference under Art. 136.
Resolving civil court jurisdiction in i4 requires application of s9 CPC concept c2
Determining if Act bars title suit in i5 requires s9 CPC test in c2

Precedent p2 similarly holds s.200(1) does not exclude civil court on title suits, supporting h1
